Update a style guide for "Float Division"

This PR updates a style guide for "Float Division".

The original issue for which this style was proposed.
https://github.com/rubocop-hq/ruby-style-guide/issues/628

It is an update based on the following argument.
https://github.com/rubocop-hq/rubocop/pull/7153#discussion_r295080040

The following is a quote from the argument about the reason for this change.

> I wanted to show the following option to make a bad case only when both have `to_f`.
>
> ```ruby
> # bad
> a.to_f / b.to_f
>
> # good
> a.to_f / b
> a / b.to_f
> a.fdiv(b)
> ```
>
> Whether `to_f` is used on the left or right depends on the nature of `a`
> or `b` parameter. On the other hand, it is redundant that `to_f` is used
> in both. At that time, I think it is better to let users choose whether
> to remove the left side `to_f` or the right side `to_f`. This is the
> reason I recommend this option to default.

Add `when` description/example to `no-then` rule

There's a PR to add a cop named `MultilineWhenThen`,
which detects `then` in multiline `when`.
https://github.com/rubocop-hq/rubocop/pull/7114
It refers to `MultilineIfThen` cop, which is based on `no-then` rule here.
So this commit adds `when` description and example to `no-then` rule,
making newly added `MultilineWhenThen` cop based on the style guide.
FYI, the discussion about this feature is here: https://github.com/rubocop-hq/rubocop/issues/7064

Use proper Title Case in section titles

Section titles were mostly auto-generated during AsciiDoc conversion,
and some of them were off, e.g. "Single line" vs "Single-line". But the
main culprit that they were not using proper Title Case.
Don't delete the CNAME on deploy

Publish to GitHub pages automatically

Fix section anchor

It seems that a leading number is not accepted as a section anchor.

Quote code in section titles

During recent AsciiDoc conversion, section titles were introduced, and
some of those titles are suboptimal in terms of readability, e.g.

    Use if case returns [[use-if-case-returns]]

Convert to AsciiDoc

AsciiDoc allows us to have native admonitions, footnotes, sane nesting
of list items, etc and to easily export the guide in various formats.
That would also make it trivial to publish a simple site from the guide
down the road if we want to.

A longer term plan is to convert all guides to AsciiDoc and maybe even
RuboCop's own documentation. RSpec and Rails style guides have been recently
converted:
  - https://github.com/rubocop-hq/rspec-style-guide/pull/97
  - https://github.com/rubocop-hq/rails-style-guide/pull/250

Suggest `String#match?` as a replacement for `Regexp#===`  (#640)

For consistent return values, favor `String#match?` (returns boolean)
over `String#=~` (returns integer or nil) when replacing `Regexp#===`
(also returns boolean).

Use descriptive heredoc delimiters

Using good delimiter names adds important information about the content
of heredoc strings, makes it easier to match opening and closing tags,
and as an added bonus, many editors will highlight code enclosed with
the correct delimiters.

Add a section on mixin grouping

This change adds a suggested rule on mixin grouping. Some rationales for
this could be:

 - Easier to see the number of dependencies for a `class` or `module`.
 - Easier and less error prone to change or remove a mixin.

Mostly, however, it is for consistency.

[Fix #574] Improve the name of a class used in an example

Proposing rule for referencing class methods in other class methods.

Using the example of a "service object" and its standard `.call` class
method that instantiates the class it's a member of, this proposer
suggests that class methods simply call other class methods, rather than
regurgitating the class name or even the `self` keyword. Many people,
including this proposer, tend to forget that `new` will (generally) Do
The Right Thing in such situations without decoration *because* the
method in `BasicObject` is overridden appropriately in `Class` and
elsewhere.

Kill the rule suggesting the use of specific reduce block argument names

It's really debatable whether using names like `a` and `e` is a good
practice.

As per the [documentation](http://ruby-doc.org/stdlib-2.3.0/libdoc/date/rdoc/DateTime.html),

reform needs to be taken into consideration. In all other cases,
using `Time` or `Date` is advisible.

Change Array check splat(*) example from "good" to "bad": (#541)

Using the splat technique `[*object]` will _always_ instantiate a new Array object, whereas

* Description of auxiliary verbs: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auxiliary_verb
* Also works nicely with RSpec predicate matchers
* https://www.relishapp.com/rspec/rspec-expectations/v/2-4/docs/built-in-matchers/predicate-matchers

fail and raise has not been adopted. This adds a new rule for the
preference and removed reference to fail.

definitions.

Don't include a trailing slash in self-closing elements.

Change the regex percent Literals to conform to style

The "good" example explaining when to use the percent literals syntax
for regex uses () delimiters, while a few lines later the guide states

I have changed this example to conform to the style guide.

Louis

Don't include a trailing slash in self-closing elements.

HTML5 spec says they're optional.

http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec-author-view/syntax.html#syntax-start-tag

Merge pull request #312 from aspiers/patch-1

Avoid if/unless at the end of a non-trivial block
Remove redundant use of synonymus folder-directory

Avoid if/unless at the end of a non-trivial block

Using an `if` or `unless` modifier at the end of a non-trivial
multi-line block requires reading all the way to the end of the block
before the reader becomes aware that the block is guarded by a
condition.

Additionally, in the case where the code is being viewed as part of a
patch, the condition at the end of the block may not even be visible
in the diff context; this can make code reviews harder.

Merge pull request #206 from mark-rushakoff/time-new-now

Prefer Time.now over Time.new

Prefer Time.now over Time.new

The documentation says now is an alias for new. I believe Time.now more
clearly conveys that it uses the current time, whereas Time.new does not
convey the current time vs. an arbitrary, empty time object.

GitHub search indicates that Time.now is far more popular:

* Time.now has [376,997 code results](https://github.com/search?l=ruby&q=time.now&source=c&type=Code)
* Time.new has [18,858 code results](https://github.com/search?l=ruby&q=time.new&source=c&type=Code)

The ratio of now:new is approximately 20:1.

Merge pull request #59 from originell/patch-1

Replace vim's auto-linebreak with highlighting of the 80th column.
fixes #52
added an example

Replace vim's auto-linebreak with highlighting of the 80th column.

This might be more preferable since it does not automatically break code or enforces you to line-break there. Sometimes it might be preferable to have lines longer than 80 characters, for example when quickly sketching out an idea. I guess this is more in the spirit of PEP8, where having a line length of 79 characters is just a recommendation and no enforcement.
